title: 106_hr2661
content: The Act titled "American Indian Education Foundation Act of 1999" amends Part B of subtitle II of title 36, United States Code, by adding a new chapter 216 for the American Indian Education Foundation. The American Indian Education Foundation is a federally chartered charitable and nonprofit corporation with perpetual existence, incorporated in the District of Columbia. It is not an agency or instrumentality of the United States and serves American Indian individuals and Bureau funded schools. The American Indian Education Foundation, a federally chartered nonprofit corporation, aims to support the Office of Indian Education Programs of the Bureau of Indian Affairs by accepting private gifts and conducting activities to enhance educational opportunities for American Indian students in Bureau funded schools. The foundation also collaborates with Federal, State, and tribal entities to further educational opportunities for American Indian students. The governing body of the foundation is the board of directors. The board of directors, also known as the `board', governs the American Indian Education Foundation. The board consists of at least 11 members, including the Secretary of the Interior and the Assistant Secretary of the Interior for Indian Affairs as nonvoting members. Board members must be U.S. citizens with knowledge or experience in American Indian education, representing diverse viewpoints. Officers of the foundation include a secretary. The officers of the American Indian Education Foundation include a secretary who serves as the chief operating officer. Board members do not receive compensation but are reimbursed for travel expenses. The foundation has the power to adopt a constitution, bylaws, and a corporate seal. The American Indian Education Foundation has the power to amend its constitution, adopt a corporate seal, make contracts, acquire and transfer property, sue and be sued, and perform acts necessary for its purposes. The foundation's principal office is in the District of Columbia, but it can operate throughout the United States. It must comply with state laws on service of process and is liable for the acts of its officers and agents. The board members are personally liable only for gross negligence in their duties. The foundation's administrative costs cannot exceed 10% of funds transferred and donations received. Appointment of officers and employees is subject to fund availability. Members of the board, officers, employees, and agents are not considered U.S. government officials. The Secretary of the Interior can transfer funds to the foundation. The Department of the Interior can transfer funds under the Act of February 14, 1931, if not prohibited by donation terms. A clerical amendment is made to the table of chapters in the United States Code. The American Indian Education Foundation is referenced in section 21601. Initial period after establishment is outlined in section 3. The Secretary of the Interior appoints initial voting members of the board of directors for the American Indian Education Foundation within 6 months of enactment. Successive boards must conform to the foundation's constitution and bylaws. The Secretary provides administrative support for a 5-year period after enactment. The Secretary of the Interior may provide support services and funds to the American Indian Education Foundation, requiring reimbursements for services and travel expenses. Reimbursements accepted will be deposited in the Treasury for current appropriations. The Secretary can continue to provide facilities and support as needed. The Secretary of the Interior may continue to provide facilities and necessary support services to the foundation on a reimbursable cost basis after the 5-year period specified.
